Back 8 years ago, I genuinely used to feel crazy for playing Rimworld. 

Like who are you gonna talk about to about that one crazy pawn who keeps setting your stockroom on fire over not eating at a table? Or about the first time you ever had to deal with a drop pod raid?

Despite all that though, I find myself looking back on everything. Not just the game itself, but gaming as a whole. And it opened my eyes to see Rimworld as more than just a game I play, but as a massive project countless amounts of people have put their minds and hearts into.

All because of other companies who:
- trickle updates out, often leaving core issues for the community to fix/deal with (often coupled with the next bullet point)
- shovel disgusting amounts DLC add-ons (sometimes numerous and unimpactful, sometimes unreasonably priced, and sometimes but not often, content that should have been in the base game)
- fail to deliver on promises without compromise, or often any communication at all
- shut their communities out, choosing stubborn ignorance over listening to the people supporting their project (often choosing a PR stance over a humane one)
- re-release the same title with little/no change (I'm lookin at you, [i] Bethesda. [/i] )


Ludeon though? 
They never abandoned Rimworld. They never pushed out cheap and lazy content. They never stopped listening to their community. They put the work in to shoot for the moon, and in turn, it paid off. The game has evolved so much over time, its nothing I would have expected it to be, even outdoing many of the biggest giants in the gaming industry. This game that has stood the test of time in a world full of cashgrabs and broken messes, and I don't believe its something many people recognize. 

From the diligent work of the bugfixing devs, to every new DLC pack that each adds new ways to build/play your colony...(especially once you begin to combine them, creating complex communities with unique aspects that grow and change as you play); its hard to name many game titles that are this well and thoroughly taken care of on all fronts. 

And that's not even to mention to absolutely [b] LEGENDARY [/b] modding community this game has. The amount of community content that is continued to be added/supported in the workshop can be a bit overwhelming at first, but becomes quite the treasure trove once you begin to get more comfortable with the games mechanics. 

I'm constantly finding myself adding so many new and amazing mods, just to sit for the next hour trying to sort through and de-conflict mods. (trust me when I say the headache of mod management is WELL worth the catharsis you will experience when you are finally able to play mods without issues)

I should wrap this review up though. I wanna really say thank you to the Ludeon Team, though, even if y'all don't read this. Without y'alls hard work and dedication to this game and its community, we would'nt be here with this absolutely stellar game that has brought so many different communities together in one place. And a HUGE thank you to all of the amazing modders who have or continue to add so many ways to spice up the game, y'all are some real g's. 

And even though I'm just one person writing a review to a sea of distant strangers, y'all have definitely made a difference not only in my life, but in the gaming world as a whole. 

More than many may initially acknowledge or recognize.

Story time: So I once opted to live entirely under a mountain during a game.

I was fed up with raids getting through my defences or crashing through my roofs, so the only way in or out of the base was down a long tunnel with a big castle gates at the end that the attackers would need to smash through.
Either side I built bunkers that I could fire out of, but the attackers couldn't get into, with the only access to the bunkers being from within my mountain base itself.

This worked really well for a time, the attackers would try to smash down the gates while being withered down by fire from both sides.
Then one day a group of weapon traders who were loitering outside of my gates were attacked by a group of raiders. We managed to kill the raiders, but not before one of their pack animals died, spilling everything it was carrying onto the ground. Plenty of nice stuff that was now "free" for me to collect.

But the main thing it had dropped was mortar rounds... hundreds of them, of all different types.
Since I didn't use mortars in my underground base, I ignored these while I collected the rest of the loot, and that's when it happened.

Another raid. I got everyone to their positions in the bunkers and engaged the enemy, who were currently wading through a sea of mortar rounds. Wouldn't it be funny if I were to hit one of those rounds and have the explosion kill all of the raiders at once? Oh look ones cooking off, this'll be grea-

The resulting chain reaction as hundreds of HE, EMP, incendiary, and anti-grain warheads went off, destroyed half of the mountain that I was living under. The raiders, as well as the colonist I had in the bunkers either side were vaporised, they didn't even leave corpses. The only survivor was a single "non-violent" colonist, that I had on stand-by in the hospital at the back of the colony.

I have over 700 hours in this game, yet I enjoy every single playthrough that I do. There's always something new, a different set of challenges to overcome, a whole new story being told.

Why RimWorld rocks â€” especially for modders and long-time players

âœ… Infinite variety & replayability
One of the strongest suits of RimWorld is that â€” thanks to procedurally generated worlds, random events, and a flexible â€œAI Storytellerâ€ system â€” no two playthroughs feel the same. 

Even after hundreds or thousands of hours â€” as you experienced â€” you can still get fresh stories, new disasters, strange â€œcultsâ€ of colonists, bizarre accidents, or unexpected heroes. 

ðŸŽ® Deep simulation + emergent storytelling
RimWorld isnâ€™t just about building a base â€” it simulates social relations, skills, psychology, injuries, medicine, environment (climate, seasons, biomes), resource management, combat, trade, travel, and more. 

Because of that, the game often â€œwrites its own storiesâ€: some colonies thrive, some collapse; sometimes a colonist becomes a hero, sometimes they go insane â€” and that unpredictability is part of what makes every run memorable. 

ðŸ”§ Modding + community = near-unlimited potential
The modding scene in RimWorld is one of its biggest strengths. There are thousands (even tens of thousands, depending on the definition) of mods on Steam Workshop â€” ranging from small quality-of-life tweaks, UI improvements, to major content overhauls (new races, new game mechanics, weapons, story-mod expansions, even total conversions). 

That means you can tailor the game exactly to your idea of fun: maybe you want hardcore survival, maybe sci-fi, maybe medieval times, maybe more realism â€” thereâ€™s almost always a mod for it. And that mod ecosystem keeps RimWorld alive and fresh, even many years after release. 

ðŸ§‘ðŸŽ¨ Sandbox freedom & player-driven goals
There is no â€œone true way to win.â€ RimWorld offers different possible victory conditions (escape by spaceship, planetary conquest, survival â€œforeverâ€, etc.) or you can just play indefinitely. 

You choose your style: drama, brutality, peaceful farming, trading, colony-building, maybe even a weird â€œcannibal + vampire + medieval techno-colonyâ€ if you feel like it. Modded or vanilla â€” itâ€™s on you. 

â¤ï¸ Great value for time invested
Given how much content, randomness, and mod-driven expansion RimWorld offers â€” many players feel that the time spent (even hundreds of hours) is totally justified. Some say that after 700-800 h they still discover new aspects. 

Where itâ€™s rough â€” what might turn some players off

âš ï¸ Steep learning curve & initial complexity
Because the game has so many systems â€” production chains, weather, moods, colonist traits, AI storyteller difficulty scaling â€” new players can easily feel overwhelmed. Without mods or guides, the early phase can be confusing. 

âš ï¸ Vanilla feels limited after a while (unless modded)
Once you figure out the â€œcore loopâ€ (build, expand, survive, repeat), vanilla RimWorld can get a bit repetitive â€” especially if you aim to â€œfinishâ€ a colony. Many people continue playing because of mods. 

Without mods or DLCs, the late-game may feel less dynamic than the early or mid game.

âš ï¸ UI, micromanagement & performance bugs (with large colonies or many mods)
When your colony grows, or you have tons of mods enabled, the UI/menu clutter or pathing / micromanagement can become annoying. Some people report performance/hit-rate issues once the game becomes very complex. 

âš ï¸ DLC / mod-dependency for maximum depth
While base game is solid, many of the newer features (or those giving big variety) come from mods or DLCs â€” so for â€œultimateâ€ RimWorld experience you often rely on external content. That may feel like dependency rather than pure vanilla design. 

My take â€” RimWorld as a â€œlifestyle sandboxâ€ (especially if you love mods)

Given that you played 800+ hours, I think youâ€™re exactly the kind of player that RimWorld was made for. Itâ€™s less a â€œgame you beat,â€ more a playground for creativity, chaos, stories, and personal challenges.
Because of mod support: you arenâ€™t locked into one experience. You can evolve the game with each run â€” go from peaceful farmers to brutal mech-hive survivors to mad space-pirate colonies â€” whichever vibe you pick.

RimWorld manages to balance structure (resources, survival needs, systems) with freedom (randomness, modding, sandbox goals, multiple win/lose conditions). That mixture creates emergent narratives â€” stories you never planned, but end up remembering.

Yes, you need patience; yes, vanilla gets stale eventually â€” but as long as you're open to mods (or just tweaking storyteller/difficulty or restart-scenarios), the game stays alive. In my view â€” RimWorld isnâ€™t just â€œa good game,â€ itâ€™s a tool for storytelling, experimentation, and chaos.

Normally I'm not a big fan of the Colony Sim and Base Building genre. I remember I got this game as a gift from a friend, and one night I was browsing my library. Soon finding this game sitting in it for years now, got bored enough to try it, and thought the mechanics would be too complicated that I'd put the game down rather quickly and not pick it back up. One tutorial and crashlanded scenario later, and here I am realizing I spent 16 hours straight on the game. Going beyond the night and the morning playing. Yet my colonists haven't even learned how to make guns yet.

This is one of the best Colony Sims by far, and is THE best Colony Sim to me. This game is a perfect balance of complexity and simplicity when it comes to details and gameplay mechanics. Complex enough to where you'll be constantly engaged with the amount of things to do, yet simple enough to where you won't feel overwhelmed and/or confused with the game's mechanics. Often you will be building the perfect base and sometimes hardly start on your technology research. This game has a great way of keeping you constantly active, with you adding more things for your colonists and defenses against the raiders. With every goal you accomplish you'll always find another. 

Most Colony Sims I've seen are either not very engaging, too laid back to where you're just waiting for colonists to finish before moving onto something else, having much wait time between events, or not very "open" like your colonists can't simply roam everywhere. This game however, does a great way of keeping you engaged. With events, quests, or raids that pops up, adding some action to the slightly laid-back gameplay. With the thanks to a storyteller of your choice responsible for causing these events, the game doesn't take too long at all with the time between raids and events. Even for things happening outside your colony. 
This game has a lot to it, and is my personal pick for those who never picked up a Colony Sim before, or loves Colony Sims in general.

RimWorld continues to be an absolute masterpiece that has only gotten better through the years of incredible updates and expansions. After countless, well 329.5 at time of writing, hours invested since this game was in Alpha, the new Odyssey expansions allows a whole new vanilla playstyle with gravships. There are fully customizable spacecraft that transform your colony into a mobile base capable of traveling across the map and even into orbit. 

Combined with the already massive library of content from all previous expansions, and the incredibly active modding community, RimWorld offers literally hundreds of hours of unique storytelling and emergent gameplay that never gets old and always leave new avenues to play. 

RimWorld also makes a distinction of calling itself a "Story Generator" over a game since I first heard of it, and that is what keeps drawing me back over the years. Every colony makes a unique story that lives on long after you move on from the save file. The multiplayer mod has given my gaming group many fun stories and inside jokes that continue into whatever games we play.

When this game consumes all of your time you could live vicariously through the life of your colony.

But be warned, disaster may strike at any moment.

TLDR: 
140'ish euros is too much of an up-front cost for new fans of the game for me to recommend it realistically.

UPDATE: (30/09/2025)
With a massive 20% to their base game, and between 10-15% between all except the newest dlc you'll still pay 122 euros for the whole package. That still puts the price of the full package at 2 AA studio games. For them to fix this they'd need to lower the prices of all old DLC to managable prices, as a religion mod (as an example) shouldn't go for 2 euros off of Silksong.

32 euros for the game. Seems fair, as it's a great game with modding compatibility built in.

Now here comes the math that makes it impossible for me to recommend the game to a new player.

Do you want detailed factions and events relative? 18 euro
Do you want religion? 18 euro
Do you want access to different races? 23,5 euro
Do you want cosmic horror elements? 23,5 euro
Do you want spaceships? 23,5 euro

Do you want access to all the mods? 138.5 euro

Noone plays the game without mods, and as such, if you want to play along with your favorite youtuber, you are expected to pay around 140 euros to do so.

Do I believe the game is worth 140 euros to a new player? Absolutely not, as there are many better experiences at a lower price point.

Plus, you'd think that for a game that copied its art basis from Prison Architect, they wouldn't be as stingy with sales as they are.

The game itself is good, but vanilla on its own isn't worthwhile imo.

It's a self-proclaimed story generator, but the stories it generates are generally of the form, "everything was going well, but then the game introduced a new kind of threat, I lost my colony, and I had to start over." It's a lot like a Paradox game that way. Like Paradox, it cost me shamefully many hours, and it never brought me joy. I need to learn to avoid these endless dopamine traps.

"Why? This game is super diverse and awesome! It's like Kenshi, but better!" You may ask. Well here is a concise answer to that:

-Being a successful animal breeder quickly leads to uncontrollable chaos the second you get a sizable herd going (overpopulation, starvation, corpses everywhere, disease, performance loss, point of no correction once performance drops even with auto-slaughter set for all animals) 
-One mad wild animal at the start of a run due to random occurrences can end an entire colony (yeah, three colonists killed by a chinchilla, screw your opinions)
-lackluster, RNG inherent trait system for initial colonists leaves you wishing for better customization of personalities 
-hearkening to the previous comment, HOW DOES A NON-VIOLENT PERSON EVEN EXIST IN THESE CONDITIONS (I'd understand if you had agoraphobic folks arise from offspring once you have a colony established, but putting the mentally ill in extremely expensive stasis for later use? Nah, give me the option to set inherent traits)
-Torrential rainfall for three months+ with no option to keep debuffs but remove animations really grinds my gears (combine this with animals breeding out of control while I tend to other chores and I just couldn't keep my run going and had to start in a new region with less rain) 
-Harshly-limited graphics options limit performance even on my 5k series once you start getting a thriving colony going 
-pathing for things like hauling not registering even when I have production buildings in a widely accessible zone is becoming a great hindrance to my enjoyment of the game. If someone has a solution to things like the biofuel processor not being usable despite being readily accessible, please let me know what it is
-even when my colonists are stacked with weapons, skills, armor, and buffs galore, all tailored to their strengths, they often get shredded by inferior lifeforms with inferior tech 
-mid-late game becomes an unstable mess where indoor environments are being registered as outdoors, and my walk-in coolers become useless as indoor/outdoor textures overlap and decay sets in 
-probably a me-issue, but my caravans often fail to form up and leave. the group just sort of gathers on the edge of my map and consistently bump into the boundary but never leave. If anyone has a solution, please let me know in the comments

"Why? This game is super diverse and awesome! It's like Kenshi, but better!" You may ask. Well here is a concise answer to that:

-Being a successful animal breeder quickly leads to uncontrollable chaos the second you get a sizable herd going (overpopulation, starvation, corpses everywhere, disease, performance loss, point of no correction once performance drops even with auto-slaughter set for all animals) 
-One mad wild animal at the start of a run due to random occurrences can end an entire colony (yeah, three colonists killed by a chinchilla, screw your opinions)
-lackluster, RNG inherent trait system for initial colonists leaves you wishing for better customization of personalities 
-hearkening to the previous comment, HOW DOES A NON-VIOLENT PERSON EVEN EXIST IN THESE CONDITIONS (I'd understand if you had agoraphobic folks arise from offspring once you have a colony established, but putting the mentally ill in extremely expensive stasis for later use? Nah, give me the option to set inherent traits)
-Torrential rainfall for three months+ with no option to keep debuffs but remove animations really grinds my gears (combine this with animals breeding out of control while I tend to other chores and I just couldn't keep my run going and had to start in a new region with less rain) 
-Harshly-limited graphics options limit performance even on my 5k series once you start getting a thriving colony going 
-pathing for things like hauling not registering even when I have production buildings in a widely accessible zone is becoming a great hindrance to my enjoyment of the game. If someone has a solution to things like the biofuel processor not being usable despite being readily accessible, please let me know what it is
-even when my colonists are stacked with weapons, skills, armor, and buffs galore, all tailored to their strengths, they often get shredded by inferior lifeforms with inferior tech 
-mid-late game becomes an unstable mess where indoor environments are being registered as outdoors, and my walk-in coolers become useless as indoor/outdoor textures overlap and decay sets in 
-probably a me-issue, but my caravans often fail to form up and leave. the group just sort of gathers on the edge of my map and consistently bump into the boundary but never leave. If anyone has a solution, please let me know in the comments
